private_information: I observe the left-most and center stacks on the table (blocks B, A, E and C, D).
I can perform standard BlocksWorld move primitives: unstack, stack, putdown, pickup, but I will only report local observations and any local action sequence I executed.
mover1.goal: Contribute observations and a local action trace so the orchestrator can build a global PDDL model and derive the final state.

private_information: I observe the right-most stack on the table (blocks G, F).
I can perform standard BlocksWorld move primitives: unstack, stack, putdown, pickup, but I will only report local observations and any local action sequence I executed.
mover2.goal: Contribute observations and a local action trace so the orchestrator can build a global PDDL model and derive the final state.

private_information: I coordinate the agents and integrate their reports into a single PDDL domain and problem targeted at the FastDownwards solver.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a complete PDDL domain and problem (FastDownwards-compatible) that represents the blocks, initial configuration, and the planned actions so the final arrangement can be derived.

public_information: There are seven blocks: A, B, C, D, E, F, G.
Standard BlocksWorld rules apply: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
Initial arrangement: on(A,B), on(B,table), on(E,A), on(C,table), on(D,C), on(F,G), on(G,table).

The agents execute this sequence of actions in order: 1. unstack(E,A) 2. stack(E,D) 3. unstack(E,D) 4. stack(E,F) 5. unstack(D,C) 6. putdown(D) 7. unstack(E,F) 8. stack(E,F) 9. unstack(E,F) 10. putdown(E).
Derive the final arrangement of each block (whether it is on the table or on top of another block) after applying the sequence above to the initial configuration.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an agent that observes part of a BlocksWorld instance. Provide a concise plaintext report of your local observations and any local action trace you executed. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on the blocks you observe and the local effects of actions you carried out if any.
pddl.prompt: Your name is mover1. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private observations: {agents->mover1->private_information}. Your purpose: {agents->mover1->goal}. Produce a clear, compact plaintext report listing the blocks you see, their local relationships (e.g., on(X,Y) or on(X,table)), and the local sequence of actions you executed (if any). Do not provide PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an agent that observes part of a BlocksWorld instance. Provide a concise plaintext report of your local observations and any local action trace you executed. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on the blocks you observe and the local effects of actions you carried out if any.
pddl.prompt: Your name is mover2. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private observations: {agents->mover2->private_information}. Your purpose: {agents->mover2->goal}. Produce a clear, compact plaintext report listing the blocks you see, their local relationships (e.g., on(X,Y) or on(X,table)), and the local sequence of actions you executed (if any). Do not provide PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent BlocksWorld PDDL modeling and planning. Integrate the agents' plaintext reports into a single coherent PDDL domain and PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Keep agent actions distinct if you model them as multiple actors. Always enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The produced PDDL must encode the standard BlocksWorld predicates and actions and represent the initial state and the final desired state(s) or the action sequence so FastDownwards can compute or verify the final arrangement.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Public information: {environment->public_information}. You received these reports: {pddl_mover1} and {pddl_mover2}. Your private information and goal: {agents->orchestrator->private_information} ; {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Integrate the reports, resolve naming or reference ambiguities, and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeted at FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure actions of different agents are identifiable if represented separately. The PDDL should allow deriving the final arrangement after the given action sequence.
